fields.headline: Richard Hawley, Coles Corner
fields.bodyText: Like Andy Warhol, endlessly printing up images of Marilyn and Brillo boxes, Richard Hawley has realised there's nothing wrong with finding your niche and burrowing in. His third album follows the template of its predecessors: romance reels at its heart, nostalgia aches in the crevices, lovers get "lost in the gloom" and lonely fellas haunt the streets hoping to meet "a girl with a flower in her hair". If there is a difference it's in the richness of the emotions and textures: with its luxurious, swelling orchestration, The Ocean feels bigger than anything Hawley has written before; Born Under a Bad Sign somehow more honeyed, lilting and tender. Earlier this year, Nancy Sinatra confessed herself a fan, and it's easy to see why: Hawley's old-fashioned, lovelorn, immaculately produced songs call to mind everything that was wonderful about Nancy's dad.
